title: Mark Selby annihilates David Gilbert in English Open final to end title dry spell
text:
Mark Selby destroyed David Gilbert in the English Open final (Picture: Getty Images)

Mark Selby produced a sensational performance in the English Open final to destroy David Gilbert 9-1 and lift his first title in over a year.

The three-time world champion made two centuries (130 and 101) and six half-centuries in a superb display in Crawley, with Gilbert’s only frame coming from a break of 101.

The former world number one had gone through a serious dry spell by his high standards, last winning an event at the China Championship last September.

However, after back-to-back semi-finals, the Jester from Leicester has returned to winnings ways and can stop ‘second guessing’ himself after his poor run.

‘Unbelievable,’ said Selby of his victory in Crawley. ‘It’s been a long time since I won my last tournament, its been tough. I’ve been second guessing myself, my family told me it has worked before and it’ll work again I just had to keep believing and thankfully I did.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘We play each other in practice a lot, when I do that I get into a rhythm and flow, and I told myself I just had to do that today. I got off to a great start and that just settled the nerves even more.

Selby is back to winning ways (Picture: VCG via Getty Images)

‘It’s fantastic, to play Dave in the final is an absolute privilege. It’s only a matter of time for him, you can’t be as good as him and not win tournaments, I expect him to win one this year and then the floodgates will open and he’ll win many more.

‘Over the moon to win another tournament on UK soil, a lot of my wins have been out in China.’

Former world number three Neal Foulds now sees Selby as a major threat at the Triple Crown events this season, having rediscovered some of his best form.

‘You look at the UK Championship and the World Championship now for Selby because there’s hardly a better player around better equipped for 17 days at the Crucible,’ Foulds said on Eurosport.

‘He’s back in that type of form now and I think whatever bookmakers have prices for him might have just taken a number off him.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

Selby admitted earlier in the week that his confidence has been a bit fragile during his search for form, but should now take great heart from this success.

‘It doesn’t matter what you’ve achieved in the game, if you keep getting beat, your confidence is going to go,’ Selby admitted.

‘You start thinking to yourself, “do I need to change something?” But I’ve watched videos and what I’m doing now is exactly the same to when I was winning, it was just the mental side of things.’
